âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: A fun puzzle to solve, waiting for Part 2 ðŸ™‚

The usage of words "length" and "width" is a bit unusal.
"w" is usually the size of the grid in the direction of x coordinate.
Here having to read and output "w" number of strings is a bit strange.
Yeah I know these are just variable names, but still.
If it is 3D city maybe max_x, max_y, max_z is better than length and width.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: nice puzzle

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Had fun with my solution.

Goal
* Please change 0 to 1 in "0 to 9 represent radius 0 to 9" since none of the current cases include light sources with radius of 0 (and they shouldn't).

* Please mention that if the [[brightness]] calculated using the formula results in a negative value, it should be treated as 0.

* The brightness of each cell from a given light source is determined by a single formula: brightness = radius - d. As such, a cell is either lit or not lit at all. There is no concept of partial lighting. The mention of a cell being lit if "50% or more of it lies within the circle" is misleading and unnecessary.

In fact, removing the -0.5 adjustment from the distance check in the code still results in correct outputs for all current cases:

def is_lit(sx, sy, x, y, r):
    [â€¦]
    d = round(dist)
    if d < r:
        return r - d
    return 0

To avoid confusion, please remove the entire paragraph on partial lighting.

Note: For simplicity, it's best to assume the brightness formula applies uniformly to a whole cell (even though the source lights up a circular area). The -0.5 adjustment isn't a reliable way to approximate coverage, and it isn't even mentioned in the statement. To be more accurate, you may need more complex calculations like here: https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/1245578040a5b479c3d0c21e0f41e44a3c7bc4 . I suggest we leave such calculations out of the scope of this puzzle.

Constraints
* Please delete "length of [[s]]" because it's defined to be equal to [[l]] and there's already a constraint on [[l]].

Cover picture
* Consider uploading a cover picture for the puzzle.

Cases
* Rural (test): Include vertically adjacent light sources, similar to Rural.1 (validator).

* TOO MUCH LIGHT (test): Include horizontally adjacent light sources, similar to TOO MUCH LIGHT.1 (validator).

Thanks.

Note: For simplicity, it's best to assume the brightness formula applies uniformly to a whole cell (even though the source lights up a circular area). The -0.5 adjustment isn't a reliable way to approximate coverage, and it isn't even mentioned in the statement. To be more accurate, you may need more complex calculations like here: https://www.codingame.com/... . I suggest we leave such calculations out of the scope of this puzzle.

-So I just say that the brightness applies uniformly to a whole cell?
Should I make a part 2 of this?
But it is a 3d city represented on a 2d map, so there cannot be 3 variables.
Part 2: https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/127197ad85ee44865c2ef7066eddaf68b858d7

max_x and max_y then.
or just swapping width and length if you insist on length

I guess so...
But I don't really think it is that necessary.

I've found this very confusing too, since the usual convention in many puzzles is to have "height" lines, each containing "width" characters. While I would definitely prefer if @Delicious31415 updated this puzzle (and all their other puzzles!) to follow that convention, it's not a dealbreaker. I can adapt by renaming the variables myself when solving, once the puzzle is approved.
Done
yea, would be nice!
Making it rn

Yes, please do.

Also, as mentioned in my last comment, please mention that if the [[brightness]] calculated using the formula results in a negative value, it should be treated as 0 (the cell is unlit).
Done

1 to 9 represent radius 1 to 9
but
0â€“9 for brightness 0â€“9

They have different ranges. Please amend 1 to 0 for the brightness range.

Thanks.
Ok
I don't have further comment for now.
